definition[0]: a small building, often made of wood, used especially for storing things
definition[1]: a large industrial building where work is done, large vehicles are kept, machinery is stored etc
definition[2]: to get rid of something that you no longer need or want
example[2]: The company is planning to shed about a quarter of its workforce.
example[3]: The magazine is desperately trying to shed its old-fashioned image.
example[4]: a diet to help you shed pounds
definition[3]: if a plant sheds its leaves or if an animal sheds skin or hair, they fall off as part of a natural process
example[5]: The trees were starting to shed their leaves.
example[6]: As it grows, a snake will regularly shed its skin.
definition[4]: to drop something or allow it to fall
example[7]: He strode across the bathroom, shedding wet clothes as he went.
example[8]: A lorry shed its load of steel bars on the M25.
definition[5]: if something sheds water, the water flows off its surface, instead of sinking into it
example[9]: The bank continued to shed workers.
example[10]: Doing exercise is the best way to shed surplus weight.
example[11]: I needed to shed a few pounds.
example[12]: Has the industry finally shed its negative image?
example[13]: As the party went on, people began to shed their inhibitions.
definition[6]: to get rid of something that you no longer need, especially workers
example[14]: Plans to shed another 10,000 employees were unveiled.
example[15]: There are companies who are making high levels of profit and who are still shedding jobs.
definition[7]: if shares shed an amount they become less in value by that amount
example[16]: The shares shed 55 cents to close at A$15.9.
